speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the knee pain? When did it start, and how would you describe the pain - sharp, dull, or aching?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about a day ago, and I would say it's a dull ache, especially on the inside of my knee, just below the kneecap.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your physical activity level before the pain started? Were you doing anything new or unusual that might have put extra stress on your knee?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been pretty active lately, I joined a volleyball team about a week ago, and we've been playing a few times a week. I was doing some pivoting and twisting movements during practice yesterday, and I think that might have put some extra stress on my knee, but it didn't really bother me until today.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pivoting and twisting movements you were doing yesterday? Were you landing from jumps, cutting, or just general quick changes of direction?

speaker: Patient
text: We were doing a lot of quick changes of direction, trying to simulate game scenarios. I was also doing some lateral shuffles and rapid pivots, which I guess put a lot of stress on my knee joint.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the type of knee pain you're experiencing now? Is it constant, or does it come and go, and do you notice any swelling or redness around the knee?

speaker: Patient
text: The pain seems to be constant, but it's more noticeable when I'm standing or walking, and it feels like it's getting a bit worse throughout the day. I don't really notice any swelling or redness around the knee, but it's a bit tender to the touch, especially on the inside.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any previous knee injuries or conditions, such as a sprain, strain, or meniscus tears? Also, have you noticed any weakness or instability in your knee, making it difficult to walk or bear weight on it?

speaker: Patient
text: I've had some issues with my knee in the past, actually. I've had to deal with some discomfort after playing sports, but I've never really had a severe injury. I've been told by my doctor that I might be prone to some issues with my joint alignment, but I don't know if that's relevant now.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the knee alignment issues you've had in the past? What kind of symptoms were you experiencing, and how did your doctor diagnose them? Also, you mentioned pivoting and twisting movements yesterday - did you notice any sensation or feeling in your knee when you were doing those movements, such as a grinding or snapping sensation?

speaker: Patient
text: I've had some issues with my knee alignment in the past, but I think it was more of a general feeling of instability, like my knee would sometimes feel like it was going to give way or wobble when I was standing or changing direction. My doctor did some X-rays and an MRI, and they found some issues with my tibia and fibula alignment, but they didn't seem too serious at the time. I just kind of brushed it off as a minor issue and continued with my usual activities. As for the sensation when I was pivoting and twisting yesterday, I wouldn't say I felt anything specific, like a grinding or snapping sensation. It was more of a dull ache, like I mentioned before, but it was also a bit of a... a feeling of wear and tear, like my knee was just getting tired and sore from all the quick changes of direction.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your knee alignment issues in the past? Did you notice any specific activities or positions that made the feeling of instability worse or better? Also, I'd like to take a look at your knee alignment and assess the joint alignment. Can you please stand up and let me examine it?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it was more noticeable when I was standing on uneven surfaces or playing sports that involved a lot of lateral movement, like volleyball. It was hard to describe, but my knee just felt like it was off-balance sometimes, like it was trying to compensate for something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the uneven surfaces that made the feeling of instability worse? Were you more prone to feeling unstable when your foot was on the ball of your foot or when it was more towards the heel? And please, stand up and let me examine your knee alignment while you're standing on a flat surface. I'd like to assess the joint alignment and check for any other signs of instability.

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say it was more when my foot was on the ball of my foot, like when I was standing on a slope or uneven ground. It felt like my knee was trying to compensate for the unevenness, but it was hard to explain.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you stand up and let me examine your knee alignment while you're standing on a flat surface? I'd like to assess the joint alignment and check for any other signs of instability. Also, I'd like to request an X-ray of your knee to get a better look at the bone structure and see if there are any signs of a fracture or other bone-related issues. REQUEST TEST: Knee_X-Ray

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: - Lower_Extremity_Examination: - Special_Tests: - Ligamentous Instability Tests: Negative - tests: - X-Ray_Knee: - Findings: No fracture, dislocation, or appreciable joint effusion.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities since the pain started? Are you able to bear weight on your knee, or does it cause you any discomfort when you walk or stand? Also, would you be willing to bend your knee slightly and show me how it feels? Sometimes it's helpful to assess the joint in different positions.

speaker: Patient
text: I've been trying to take it easy, but I've been doing some light activities like watching TV and going for short walks around the block. As for bearing weight, it's not too bad, but it does feel a bit sore, especially when I'm standing for a long time. When I bend my knee slightly, I feel a bit of pressure on the inside, like it's putting extra stress on the joint.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities since the pain started? Are you able to bear weight on your knee, or does it cause you any discomfort when you walk or stand? Also, would you be willing to bend your knee slightly and show me how it feels? (Please note that I will ask only 10 more questions after this, and then I will make a diagnosis)

speaker: Patient
text: I've been trying to take it easy, but I've been doing some light activities like watching TV and going for short walks around the block. As for bearing weight, it's not too bad, but it does feel a bit sore, especially when I'm standing for a long time. When I bend my knee slightly, I feel a bit of pressure on the inside, like it's putting extra stress on the joint.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your knee pain when you bend it slightly? Does it feel like there's a specific point where it starts to hurt, or is it more of a gradual increase in pressure as you bend the knee?

speaker: Patient
text: When I bend my knee slightly, it feels like there's a point where the pressure on the inside of my knee starts to build up, and it becomes more noticeable. It's not exactly a sharp pain, but more of a dull ache that gets a bit more intense as I bend the knee further.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the point where the pressure on the inside of your knee starts to build up? Is it a specific angle or position that makes it worse, or does it seem to be more consistent across different knee bends?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say it's more consistent across different knee bends, but it's a bit more noticeable when my foot is on the ball of my foot. When I'm standing or walking, it feels like my knee is trying to compensate for the unevenness, like it's putting extra stress on the joint.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request an MRI of your knee to get a better look at the soft tissue and ligaments. REQUEST TEST: Knee_MRI Also, I'd like to assess the range of motion in your knee. Can you please bend your knee to 90 degrees and then straighten it again for me?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Lower_Extremity_Examination: - Inspection: No visible abnormalities, erythema, or swelling. - Palpation: Tenderness over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella. - Range_of_Motion: Full range of motion without significant pain or limitation. - Special_Tests: Negative for ligamentous instability tests. tests: X-Ray_Knee: - Findings: No fracture, dislocation, or appreciable joint effusion. speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like the X-ray and physical examination didn't reveal any obvious fractures or joint effusion. speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of tenderness over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella? Is it a sharp pain, or more of a dull ache, and does it radiate to any other areas?

speaker: Patient
text: It's more of a dull ache, to be honest. It doesn't really radiate to any other areas, but it's definitely more noticeable when I'm standing or walking. It feels like there's pressure building up in that area, like my knee is trying to compensate for something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the activities that make the pressure on the inside of your knee worse? For example, are there specific movements, positions, or activities that make the tenderness more noticeable?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it's more noticeable when I'm standing on uneven surfaces or playing sports that involve a lot of lateral movement, like volleyball. The pressure on the inside of my knee feels like it's building up when my foot is on the ball of my foot, like when I'm standing on a slope or uneven ground. It's hard to explain, but it feels like my knee is trying to compensate for the unevenness, like it's putting extra stress on the joint.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about how you've been managing your knee pain since it started? Have you been taking any pain medication, and if so, what kind?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been trying to take it easy, but I've been doing some light activities like watching TV and going for short walks around the block. I've also been icing the area a few times a day to try and reduce the swelling. I haven't been taking any specific pain medication, but I did try some over-the-counter ibuprofen yesterday after the pain started.

speaker: Doctor
